text: Two blocks of masses 10 kg and 4 kg are connected by a spring of negligible mass and placed on a frictionless horizontal surface. An impulse gives a velocity of 14 m/s to the heavier block in the direction of the lighter block. What is the velocity of the centre of mass?

ncert_mapping.chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

steps.description: Identify that spring force is internal to the system
steps.explanation: Since the surface is frictionless and spring connects the blocks, there's no external horizontal force on the system

steps.description: Apply centre of mass velocity formula
steps.explanation: Initially, only the 10 kg block is moving with 14 m/s, the 4 kg block is at rest
Both momenta are equal, confirming our answer

official_solution.answer_justification: Option (c) is correct. The centre of mass moves with constant velocity 10 m/s since no external force acts on the system.

common_mistakes.mistake: Taking average of velocities instead of weighted average
common_mistakes.correct_approach: Must use mass-weighted average: (m₁v₁ + m₂v₂)/(m₁ + m₂)

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking spring force affects CM motion
common_mistakes.correct_approach: Spring force is internal; CM velocity remains constant

alternative_approaches.explanation: Total momentum before = Total momentum of CM

key_insights: Centre of mass velocity is independent of internal forces
Spring force doesn't change the CM motion
Mass-weighted average is crucial for CM calculations

text: Two particles A and B initially at rest, move towards each other by mutual force of attraction. At the instant when the speed of A is v and the speed of B is 2v, what is the speed of the centre of mass of the system?
concepts_required: Centre of mass for isolated system

ncert_mapping.chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

steps.explanation: The mutual force of attraction between A and B is an internal force to the system

steps.description: Apply the principle for isolated systems
steps.explanation: Since no external force acts on the system, the velocity of centre of mass remains constant
Initially both particles are at rest, so initial velocity of CM = 0
Since both started from rest, total initial momentum = 0. By conservation, total momentum always = 0, hence v_CM = 0

official_solution.answer_justification: Option (d) is correct. The centre of mass remains at rest throughout the motion since the system was initially at rest and no external force acts on it.

common_mistakes.correct_approach: Must consider that particles move in opposite directions and use vector addition

common_mistakes.consequence: Gets option (c) without considering masses or directions
common_mistakes.correct_approach: Apply conservation of momentum for isolated system

common_mistakes.consequence: Not recognizing system started from rest
common_mistakes.correct_approach: Initial momentum = 0, so CM velocity is always zero

alternative_approaches.explanation: Let masses be m_A and m_B. Since they move towards each other: m_A·v - m_B·2v = 0
alternative_approaches.formula: This gives m_B = m_A/2, and v_CM = (m_A·v - m_B·2v)/(m_A + m_B) = 0

key_insights: For isolated system, CM velocity is constant
Mutual forces are internal and don't affect CM motion
If system starts from rest, CM remains at rest
Individual particles can have high speeds while CM is stationary

text: A body of mass 2 kg makes an elastic collision with a second body at rest and continues to move in the original direction but with one-fourth of its original speed. What is the mass of the second body?

ncert_mapping.chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

steps.explanation: Let M be the mass of second body, v₂' its final velocity

steps.description: Apply coefficient of restitution for elastic collision

official_solution.answer_justification: Option (b) is correct. The mass of the second body is 1.2 kg.

common_mistakes.consequence: Gets two unknowns (M and v₂') with one equation
common_mistakes.correct_approach: Must use both momentum conservation and e = 1 condition
Problem states it continues in original direction, so v₁' is positive

alternative_approaches.formula: ½mv² = ½m(v/4)² + ½Mv₂'² and mv = m(v/4) + Mv₂'

key_insights: Elastic collision requires both momentum and energy conservation
Coefficient of restitution e = 1 for elastic collision
Lighter object can continue in original direction after collision
Two conservation laws needed for two unknowns

text: A body of mass 1 kg initially at rest, explodes and breaks into three fragments of masses in the ratio 1:1:3. The two pieces of equal mass fly-off perpendicular to each other with a speed of 30 m/s each. What is the velocity of the heavier fragment?

ncert_mapping.chapter: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

steps.calculation: Ratio 1:1:3, Total = 1+1+3 = 5 parts; Each part = 1/5 kg
steps.result: m₁ = m₂ = 0.2 kg (equal masses), m₃ = 0.6 kg (heavier fragment)

steps.explanation: p⃗₁ + p⃗₂ + p⃗₃ = 0⃗, therefore p⃗₃ = -(p⃗₁ + p⃗₂)

steps.description: Set up coordinate system and find momentum components
steps.explanation: Let fragment 1 move along +x axis, fragment 2 along +y axis
steps.calculation: p₁ = 0.2 × 30 î = 6î kg·m/s; p₂ = 0.2 × 30 ĵ = 6ĵ kg·m/s

steps.result: Direction: tan⁻¹(-6/-6) = 225° from +x axis (or 45° in third quadrant)

official_solution.answer_justification: Option (a) is correct. The heavier fragment moves with velocity 10√2 m/s at 45° to the horizontal in the direction opposite to the resultant of the two lighter fragments.

common_mistakes.correct_approach: Initial momentum = 0, so final momentum vector sum = 0

common_mistakes.mistake: Scalar addition instead of vector addition
common_mistakes.correct_approach: Must use vector addition: √(30² + 30²) for perpendicular components

common_mistakes.consequence: Using equal masses for all fragments

alternative_approaches.explanation: Find resultant of p₁ and p₂, then p₃ is equal and opposite
alternative_approaches.formula: p_resultant = √(p₁² + p₂²) = 6√2 kg·m/s at 45°, so p₃ is opposite

key_insights: Explosion is internal force, doesn't change total momentum
For body at rest, final momentum vector sum = 0
